 Fallacy Alert . . .
 Negative proof
 
 The fallacy of appealing to lack of proof of the negative is a type of logical fallacy of the following form:
  "This exists because there is no proof that it does not exist."
 Non-fallacious ways to prove something include the use of logical syllogisms and/or the incorporation of empirical observations. But it is not logical to argue that something exists simply because there is no proof to the contrary; one cannot say, "No one has proven that aliens do not exist. Therefore, based on that alone, they must exist, notwithstanding that I have no evidence that they do exist". Given (as it is above) that it was not proven that aliens do not exist, they might exist, but this alone does not prove them to exist.
 
 Another common example is that, "A supernatural force must exist because there is no proof that it does not exist". However, the converse is also true, according to the Argument from Ignorance: One also cannot say that, "I have not seen proof that something supernatural exists, therefore a supernatural force cannot exist". Also, similar to the aliens in the above example, since no proof is available that this does not exist, it might exist, but this alone does not prove it to exist. 
 http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negative_proof

 IMHO, verbal assault, and even worse, the kind of "hate mongering" that often goes hand in hand with these speeches and speakers, can potentially lead to an equal amount of harm being done to both people, and society in general, than a pie in the face, both are equally disrespectful, and both are equally assinine.
 
 Giving someone a pass, or somehow downgrading their actions because they are verbal rather than physical, "so they aren't that big of a deal in comparison" is completely unacceptable IMHO. The pen indeed can be more powerful than the sword.

 We have something called "freedom of speech" here in the US. We don't have a "freedom to assault" here in the US. That's the biggest difference that I see.
 

 I just don't understand how inviting or paying someone to speak gives them a free pass on the content of their speech, or the right to be intentionally disrespectful. The person at the podium is free to speak, and those in the audience are free to come and go, but disrespect on the part of the speaker is still disrespect, regardless of the situation. Perhaps you can explain why you feel otherwise?

 Certainly, I will endeavor to do so. If I go to listen to a speaker, I'm 1) not going to be surprised at what he says, 2) made the effort to hear what HE has to say. I didn't make the effort to go hear a heckler or see a piethrower attempt to prevent the speaker from talking.3) "disrespecting" someone doesn't give them carte blanche to do as they please. There is no right to not be disrespected. If your skin's that thin, don't attend the speech.
 

 They cancel out IMHO, disrespect is disrespect, and both actions are disrespectful. IMHO, one is no more disrespectful than the other, and I believe you'd have a hard time making a case to the contrary.

 See above.
 

 You seem to be intentionally blind to the fact that that regardless of who the audience is, or whether or not I agree with the speaker, the speech is still disrespectful. A person can "speak their mind" without being disrespectful. 
 
 My point here is not that interrupting the speech is not disrespectful, of course it is, and two wrongs don't make a right. My point is simply that if the speech itself is disrespectful, regardless of time, place, or audience, then how is that form of disrespect somehow OK, while the other form of disrespect (interuptions) is not, or is somehow worse? 
 
 IMHO, you're playing a rather random game of defining disrespect to suit your cause.Waxy
